learning_outcomes.description: Recognise and understand the meaning of - the mathematical notation for matrices and vectors
Recognise and understand the meaning of - set notation and mathematical functions, the composition, inverse and the limit of functions
Recognise and understand the meaning of - the derivative of a function
Recognise and understand the meaning of - complex numbers represented in cartesian, exponential and polar form
Recognise and understand the meaning of - the Fundamental Theorm of Algebra, De Moivre's Theorem and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
Recognise and understand the meaning of - integration as the antiderivative of a function and as the limit of a Riemann sum
Express/manipulate - mathematical ideas using matrix and vector notation
Express/manipulate - simple functions and represent them graphically
Express/manipulate - equations involving complex numbers using the complex conjugate and represent a complex number on an Argand diagram
Calculate/Evaluate - the solution to inequalities and express them graphically

Calculate/Evaluate - the limit of a simple function, the derivative of simple functions using the limits formula, the constant multiple, sum, product and quotient rules of differentiation, and the derivative of a relation
Calculate/Evaluate - critical points of a function, and use the first and second derivative tests to sketch the graph of a function
Calculate/Evaluate - the Riemann sum to estimate the area under a curve and evaluate an integral using a substitution
Calculate/Evaluate - equations of lines and planes and solve problems concerning lines and planes
Apply/Model - physical problems using matrices and vectors
Apply/Model - mathematical induction to prove mathematical statements
Apply/Model - differentiation and integration to solve applied problems
Apply/Model - the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, De Moivre's Theoremand the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra

assessments.due_date: Weeks 4, 6, 7 or 8 (depending on the timing of the in-semester exam), 9, 12, 13.
assessments.task_description: You will complete a collaborative exercise at the applied class.
assessments.submission_guidelines: In class - Hand in the collaborative exercise to your casual academic at the end of the applied class.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
You must submit detailed written solutions to a collection of mathematical problems.

Assignments are released approximately 10 days before the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
In-semester Saturday

6/09/2025 - 20/09/2025

You must hold all of the following three Saturdays free until the exam date is officially announced

  • 6 September 2025 (week 6)
  • 13 September 2025 (week 7)
  • 20 September 2025 (week 8)
assessments.task_description:
The examination will be invigilated on-campus.

The total time for the exam is 10 minutes (planning time) + 90 minutes (working time). 

There will be a range of short-answer and problem solving questions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Independent work

During the semester students are expected to work on MATH1050 outside of class time to consolidate the information given during lectures, work on problem sheets and assignments, complete extra practice problems and study for examinations. This semester you have access to a UQ Extend website which contains extra resources. The UQ Extend site link is on Blackboard.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13, L14, L15, L16, L17, L18
learning_activities.topic_description: Independent work During the semester students are expected to work on MATH1050 outside of class time to consolidate the information given during lectures, work on problem sheets and assignments, complete extra practice problems and study for examinations. This semester you have access to a UQ Extend website which contains extra resources. The UQ Extend site link is on Blackboard.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Lectures define the course material. They set out the basic theory and demonstrate techniques for problem solving. They cover all the core material required for the course. While watching the lecture recordings, students are expected to annotate their course notes as the lecturer works through the notes, and complete the examples in the course notes. This semester you have access to a UQ Extend website which contains extra resources (pre-recorded videos, quizzes and interactive animations). The UQ Extend site link is on Blackboard.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13, L14, L15, L16, L17, L18

learning_activities.topic:
Weekly applied class

Applied classes provide students with an opportunity for individual assistance. Students will need to download a set of problems from the course website to complete before and during each class, giving them the opportunity to practise mathematical techniques with assistance available from a casual academic and/or from their peers. The casual academics may also encourage group discussion on the questions covered on the problem sheets. Students will complete a collaborative exercise at the applied class in the weeks indicated under Assessment, and hand in the exercise at the end of the applied class. Casual academics may also provide assistance with assignments and other aspects of the course.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13, L14, L15, L16, L17, L18
